item.title: Some of the best Nintendo Switch games are up to $30 off for Black Friday
item.content:encoded:
You can also grab a handful of discounted amiibo, including a few based on The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom.

You can also grab a handful of discounted amiibo, including a few based on The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom.

by

Nov 23, 2025, 7:00 PM UTC

Brandt Ranj

is a commerce reporter for The Verge writing about the best deals and gadgets. He previously wrote for Business Insider, Rolling Stone, Futurism, and Popular Science.

Nintendo has made some of the most iconic video games of all time, but building a library of the standouts can quickly become expensive, especially given that many titles donâ€™t often go on sale at a significant discount. The good news is that Nintendo is already running a holiday sale in the run-up to Black Friday, allowing you to save on Nintendo Switch games, amiibo, and accessories through November 28th.

The biggest news is that Nintendo and select retailers are offering some of the Switchâ€™s best games â€” including Super Mario Odyssey and The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom â€” for as little as $29.99, which amounts to a healthy $30 discount. In some cases, these games are at their lowest price ever, and we donâ€™t expect any of them to be this heavily discounted again until â€œMAR10 Dayâ€ rolls around next year.

Typically, Nintendo offers a discount on a Switch bundle that includes a digital copy of Mario Kart: 8 Deluxe or some other first-party title, but that doesnâ€™t seem to be happening this year. The company has openly admitted that itâ€™s shifting its focus to the Switch 2 â€” which isnâ€™t on sale and isnâ€™t expected to be anytime soon â€” and recently raised the price of the original Switch due to President Trumpâ€™s tariff policy.

Sadly, no Switch 2 games are part of the promo; however, you can play the discounted OG Switch titles on Nintendoâ€™s latest console. Plus, if you are looking for deals related to the Switch 2, Woot is still running a video game promo through the end of today, November 23rd, giving you a chance to save on newer releases like Mario Kart World and the Switch 2 Edition of The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild.

$30

Super Mario Odyssey remains one of the crowning achievements of the original Switch thanks to its tight platforming, ingenious level design, and a game mechanic that lets you control certain enemies and parts of the environment. There are still bosses to battle and coins to collect, but Odyssey feels like a breath of fresh air. Read our review.

$30

Princess Peach: Showtime! is the first Nintendo game to star the Mushroom Kingdom royal in nearly 20 years, and itâ€™s a welcome return to form. Peach finds herself having to fight, puzzle, and platform her way through different sets in a community theater. She inhabits a different role â€” with different abilities â€” in each stage, which keeps the game engaging. Read our review.

$30

Donkey Kong Country HD is the definitive version of the tough-as-nails platformer, which initially launched on the Wii in 2016. Donâ€™t let the gameâ€™s cartoonish art, bopping soundtrack, and side-scrolling gameplay fool you, though; it will test your skills. That said, itâ€™s still a blast to work your way through the gameâ€™s tougher sections, which require both precision and patience. Read our review.

$30

Echoes of Wisdom finally lets you play as Nintendoâ€™s titular heroine. The gameâ€™s basic premise revolves around trying to save the world using the fabled Tri Rod, an item that allows you to replicate the spirits of items and enemies you encounter along the way. The game mixes the top-down perspective of 2D Zelda games with gameplay from the seriesâ€™ newer, open-world 3D entries. Read our review.

$40

Luigiâ€™s Mansion 3 is the seriesâ€™s most ambitious title, even though it retains the Luigi-as-a-Ghostbuster gameplay the series has employed since 2001. It takes place in a haunted hotel overrun with ghosts. To deal with them, youâ€™ll need the help of Gooigi, a doppelgÃ¤nger made of goop that can help you explore every nook and cranny. The gameâ€™s slapstick humor outweighs any spookiness. Read our review.

$30

Nintendo Switch Sports didnâ€™t change the world the way Wii Sports did in 2006, but it remains a fun party game. You can choose from six sports, including tennis and bowling, and use a single Switch Joy-Con as a motion controller. Thereâ€™s an element of â€œswing the controller and hope the correct action happens on screen,â€ but itâ€™s still a good time to play with friends. Read our review.

$30

Paper Mario: The Thousand-Year Door is generally regarded as the best Mario RPG, and the Switch remake is well worth revisiting. Mario has more paper-like abilities than he did in the original Paper Mario game (including the option to turn into a paper airplane), and Nintendo didnâ€™t feel the need to shake up the battle system or other gameplay elements like they did in subsequent entries.

$17

Splatoon 3 is the latest entry in Nintendoâ€™s paint-laden shooter franchise, and the hook this time around is a deeper single-player mode. Youâ€™ll assume the role of an undercover agent fighting through a city using a mix of shooting and platforming. As you progress, youâ€™ll begin to find artifacts of the pre-apocalypse that shine a light on what happened in the Splatoon universe. Read our review.

$40

Kirbyâ€™s Return to Dream Land Deluxe is another HD remake of a Wii game, but it introduces additional abilities, mini games, and an entirely new section thatâ€™s available once you complete the original story. The game doesnâ€™t shake up the Kirby formula, but itâ€™s still a fun game to play â€” especially with friends, as it supports four-player local co-op.

$10

Tulin is a Rito and the Sage of Wind from The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom. His amiibo will grant random items in both The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild and its aforementioned sequel.

$10

Yunobo is a Goron and the Sage of Fire from The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom. Using his amiibo will drop random items in both that game and The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild.

$10

Riju is a Gerudo and the Sage of Lightning from The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom. Using her amiibo will drop random items in both that game and The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild.

$10

Sidon is a Zora and the Sage of Water from The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom. Using his amiibo will drop random items in both that game and The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild.

$15

Jamie is a character in Street Fighter 6, and using his amiibo lets you save his outfit, color, and your own custom button settings. The amiibo also unlocks in-game rewards, including music and wallpaper.

item.title: Expedition 33 Actor Speaks Out on Game Awards Nomination
item.content:encoded:
One of the actors nominated at The Game Awards for Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 has spoken up about his surprise nod. Even more so, the actor goes as far as to credit the nomination to his French counterpart.

As one of 2025â€™s biggest games, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 seemingly came out of nowhere to some. Sporting incredible turn-based combat and excellent performances, itâ€™s no wonder it broke records at this yearâ€™s Game Awards. Its most impressive feat is having three of its cast (Ben Starr, Jennifer English, and Charlie Cox) nominated for Best Game Performance. Still, it seems one of the actors has responded to the nomination, and in a pretty interesting way.

Charlie Cox Credits Maxence Cazorla for Game Awards 2025 Nomination

In a video at La Conve/Animex in Mexico, Daredevil actor Charlie Cox is asked about his nomination for his role as Gustave in Clair Obscur: Expedition 33. Humbly, the actor credits the nomination to Maxence Cazorla, who played and did motion capture for the role in French. Cazorla also plays Esquie in both the French and English dubs of the title. Charlieâ€™s response, seen in the video, is available below,

â€œIâ€™m thrilled for this nomination,â€ says Cox. â€œIâ€™ve said this before, and I think itâ€™s important to sayâ€¦thereâ€™s an amazing French actor by the name of Maxence Cazorla, who did almost all of the motion capture for that role in that game [Clair Obscur: Expedition 33]. Any nomination or any credit I get, I really have to give to him. The performance of that character is really down to him, and my voice just was part of that process.â€œ

Even still, fans were quick to praise Charlieâ€™s great performance. Without getting into spoilers, Gustave is essential to the narrative, so itâ€™s not surprising to see Charlie get his flowers. However, Coxâ€™s co-stars, Jennifer English (Maelle) and Ben Starr (Verso), are hot off Golden Joystick wins, so they do have a better chance. The three are going up against Silent Hill fâ€™s Konatsu Kato, Indiana Jones and the Golden Circleâ€™s Troy Baker, and Ghost of Yoteiâ€™s Erika Iishi. Weâ€™ll know who takes the trophy home on December 11th, 2025.

What do you think of Charlie Coxâ€™s response to his Game Awards nomination? Do you think he deserves the nod? Who do you think is winning Best Performance? Let us know in the comments and on the official Insider Gaming Discord!

For more Clair Obscur, check out our articles on the franchiseâ€™s future and new content. Donâ€™t forget to subscribe to our weekly newsletter!
